bibl.title: Letter from John P. Corrigan to Henry Hanson, August 13, 1921

div1.p: Corrigan describes inspections of various Peruvian sites for yellow fever eradication.

div1.head: Letter from John P. Corrigan to Henry Hanson, August 13, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
---
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----
Copy:
Casma - August 13th, 1921
Dr. Henry Hanson,
Director - Campaña Sanitaria.
Chiclayo - Peru.
Sir:
div1.p:
My last report was mailed to your office at Chiclayo,
from Hacienda “Buena Vista”, July 21st, 1921. Therefore, this report
will record our activities since that date.

Mr. Arturo Sainz and I inspected Hacienda “Santa Clara”,
Guadalupito, July 23rd, Houses visited 75. Total containers 95.
Containers with larvae 1, with pupae 1. Houses closed 7.
The scarcity of larvae here was undoubtedly due to the presence
of “camarones” (shrimps), in most all containers. These are
brought in with the water delivered by the “aguadores”. Later we p
placed fish in all containers at this place.

We arrived at Tambo Real July 23rd. This is a hacienda
with a population of about 2,000. The percentage of larvae found
in the containers was about 30. We placed fish in all containers
and had plenty of time to note the excellent results. As a general
rule, on the second day after distributing fish; a few larvae
are found; but I have never found any after the third day; even in
containers which were formerly alive with larvae and pupae.

We worked between Guadalupito, Tambo Real, Santa,
Puerto of Santa and the Hacienda “San Bartolo” until July 31st,
and had fish in all containers at these places on that date.

On August 1st, we arrived at Chimbote. We had considerable
trouble in securing fish for that place, and were compelled to leave
there on August 7th, with fish in all containers excepting those
in 32 houses. We strained the water in all of these, and asked Dr.
Tapia to send fish to the “Alcalde” to finish the work. There
are about 70 wells in Chimbote. We noted stegomyia breeding
in all that were walled up by barrels, boards, or mason work.
In the earthen wells we found culex only. Ad our supply of fish
were scarce, we oiled these wells with heavy films of kerosene.
But I am anxious to get fish in all of them as the breeding at
that place was 100 per cent.

Mr. John S. Thomas, of Santa, was employed effective
August 10th, to act as Visitador for Santa and all the above mention-
ed places, at a salary of £p.8.0.00, per month; £p.2.0.00 of this
amount to pay for the use of his horse, which he will need on his
work.

We arrived at Samanca Sunday afternoon, August 7th,
and at once started a search for fish in a nearby lagoon.
The following morning we found all the fish placed in
fresh water containers by us the day before, dead, as the
water in the lagoon was “agua media salobre”. We noticed,
however, that the only containers in Samanca in which
larvae was not present, were those in which we found “renaquajos”,
or tadpoles. As we had to wait until the following day for
transportation to San Jacinto, where we could get fish, we
collected about 1,000 tadpoles and placed five or six in
each container. The following day, July 9th, we left for
San Jacinto and inspected 160 houses there. We found 2
containers with larvae and pupae. On July 10th, we went
in search for fish, and secured enough for Samanco, where
we went and placed them the following day, July 11th. We
especially noticed that there were very few places larvae
in any of the containers at Samanca, and that the tadpoles
had done excellent work, showing that they may be used in
an emergency, when there is a scarcity of fish. The
breeding at Samanco was about ninety per cent.

On July 12th, we took fish to San Jose, a town of
300 inhabitants, and found no breeding. We went on to Nepeña,
which has a polulation of 1800. We met the entire “CONSEJOrdquo;,
and at once started out putting fish in all containers.
A great many containers already had fish, but the breeding
there was about 30 per cent. We left a good supply of fish
with the “Municipalidad”, for houses that were closed during our
inspections, and which the members of the council agreed to
take care of.

On August 13th we finished our inspection of San Jacinto,
and in 150 houses found only one container with larvae. This made a
total of four containers out of 310 houses counting the 160
for July 9th, or a little over one per cent.

As the percentage of larvae found at San Jacinto was so
small, we decided not to lose time placing fish in containers
there. Mr. Gordon, Administrador General of San Jacinto is
arranging to secure fish, and will have one of the chemists
employed on the hacienda, distribute them in the containers.

On August 13th we left San Jacinto for Casma - by Samanco -
but had tomwait at the latter place until the 15th for a boat.
In the meantime we inpsevted containers at Samanco and found
that the fish had disposed of all the larvae, not one larvae
being found in any containers.

We reached the Port of Casma, August 15th, and the town
of Casma that night. The following afternoon, August 16th., 700
fish arrived from Trujillo in good condition and we started to
distribute them; Dr. Caballero and the “alcalde” assisting us.
We finished this work on the evening of August 17th. Dr. Caballero
had already distributed fish in many houses before our arrival,
and an inspection of the containers where he had placed fish
showed that they had disposed of all the larvae. The breeding in
the town of casma had been about 15 per cent.

To-morrow, Friday the 19th, we will re-examine the con-
tainers where we distributed the fish to see the result.

Dr. Caballero believes it would be well for us to inspect
Supe, and all the surrounding places. There will be a
boat leaving the Port of Casma, Sunday the 21st, for Chimbote.
Chimbote is the only place that we have worked during our trip,
that we are not entirely satisfied with, so we are planning to
work the Port of Casma Saturday, August the 20th, and leave
there for Chimbote woth boat on the 21st. The same steamer will
return south to Chimbote about the 25th, and if everything
goes well we will catch it for Supe and work that place.
I have asked Dr. Tapia to send us fish to Supe, by the same boat.
In the interval, between the 21st and the 25th, we will have
an oppurtunity to look over our work at Tambo Real, Santa,
Guadalupito, Port of Casma, Hacienda San Botolo, and Chimbote.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, (signed) J. P. Corrigan,
Inspector Sanitario.
